title: Is continuously rewriting a short story a decent method of advancing someone’s writing ability? - Quora

response.answer_text: I don’t think so. There are only so many changes you can make to a short story before making more is pointless or even detrimental. When you reach the point where you’re changing stuff just to change stuff, you’ve gone too far. What aspects of writing ability are you trying to improve? Plot pacing, worldbuilding, and character development? There’s not much word-count room for those in a short story anyway, so unless you’re working on improving your “economy of word,” you’d be better off using a novelette/novella for improving these skills. You should also keep in mind that much of the “big picture” aspect of writing is down to personal taste: there is no single “right way” to show characterization, to describe a setting, or to advance the plot. There’s no one “correct” narrative voice; if it works for that story, it’s good. Unless you know what you’re aiming for with these things, rewriting a story won’t do anything except give you a lot of practice typing. If you want to improve your skills with the “trivia” (those are sarcasm quotes, kids) of grammar and punctuation, you shouldn’t need to continuously rewrite a story to get it right. (Need help actually learning grammar and punctuation so you don’t have to rely on the often-wrong Grammarly or some other grammar-bot program? I recommend the Grammar Girl website, although I’m also rather partial to the “Writing Glitch” posts on North of Andover. The latter contains a lot of snarky humor, if you’re into that sort of thing.)
